sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_1: Find the antiderivative for the function f(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x - 9.
message_2:
To find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x - 9, we will apply the power rule for integration, which states that the antiderivative of x^n is (x^(n+1))/(n+1) + C, where C is the constant of integration.

So, for f(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x - 9, we have:

∫(5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x - 9) dx = 5∫(x^4) dx - 2∫(x^3) dx + 6∫(x) dx - 9∫(1) dx

Now, we apply the power rule:

= 5(x^(4+1))/(4+1) - 2(x^(3+1))/(3+1) + 6(x^(1+1))/(1+1) - 9(x^(0+1))/(0+1) + C

= 5(x^5)/5 - 2(x^4)/4 + 6(x^2)/2 - 9(x^1)/1 + C

= x^5 - (1/2)x^4 + 3x^2 - 9x + C

So, the antiderivative of f(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x - 9 is F(x) = x^5 - (1/2)x^4 + 3x^2 - 9x + C.
